document.title: The effect of corn on the utilization of L-tryptophan for pyridine nucleotide synthesis.
document.abstract: Pellagra was first associated with maize consumption in 1789, but its relationship to the disease was not understood at that time. Some researchers as early as 1924 hypothesized that pellagra might be caused by a deficiency of the amino acid tryptophan since this ~mino acid was missing from zein, the major protein in corn. However, it was not until 1945 that Krehl et al. Other investigators have shown that the addition of various proteins, such as zein and gelatin, or certain amino acids, or combinati~ ns of certain amino acids to a niacin-deficient low-protein diet depresses growth in rats and interferes with the utilization of tryptophan.
